description: In this series, Daniel and Justin walk you through an in-depth primer on the Python programming language. Whether you have some other programming experience or you are completely new to coding, you will be given the tools necessary to get started writing programs with Python. They cover topics like printing output to the screen, assigning and utilizing variables, getting input from the user, decision making, iteration/loops, creating lists, dictionaries, and tuples, using and creating functions, slicing, and more. If you're looking for an easy programming language to get started, or you want to add another language to your repertoire, Python is a great choice.
name: Python Programming
subtitle: Programming Language

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin give a general overview of what to expect in the upcoming Python programming series. They cover topics like who is the intended audience, what the scope of the series will cover, and what are some specific topics that will be addressed.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[SOUND]

2

starring my good friend here, Mr.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin kick things off by explaining what Python is and giving a little history of the language. They also talk about what a program is and why Python is so powerful. Then they show you how to acquire Python if it's not already installed on your system. Finally, they show you how to write your first simple Python program.
episodes.title: Setting up Python
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.150 --> 00:00:03.702
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03.702 --> 00:00:07.869
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.869 --> 00:00:08.990
All right.

4
00:00:08.990 --> 00:00:12.140
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of ITPro TV.

5
00:00:12.140 --> 00:00:13.930
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

6
00:00:13.930 --> 00:00:17.840
And in today's episode, we are beginning
our Python programming series.

7
00:00:17.840 --> 00:00:21.830
And joining us on the studio today to
lend his expertise on that very topic

8
00:00:21.830 --> 00:00:24.020
is my good friend Mr. Justin Denisson.

9
00:00:24.020 --> 00:00:25.120
Justin, welcome to the show sir.

10
00:00:25.120 --> 00:00:25.960
How you doing today?

11
00:00:25.960 --> 00:00:27.740
>> I'm doing well, thank you Daniel.

12
00:00:29.100 --> 00:00:34.980
Really excited to dive in and show
the intricacies and the wonder of Python,

13
00:00:34.980 --> 00:00:38.470
but there is a little bit
to get started first.

14
00:00:38.470 --> 00:00:39.110
>> Yeah that's right.

15
00:00:39.110 --> 00:00:41.040
We have to set the stage as it were.

16
00:00:41.040 --> 00:00:43.040
Give you guy a little bit of information,

17
00:00:43.040 --> 00:00:46.210
like a good place to start would
probably be, what is Python?

18
00:00:46.210 --> 00:00:50.590
We're talking Python is usually something
referred to as a large snake, but

19
00:00:50.590 --> 00:00:52.770
obviously not in this instance,

20
00:00:52.770 --> 00:00:55.530
we're doing IT, I even know
some of you might have pythons.

21
00:00:55.530 --> 00:00:59.006
We're talking specifically about
the programming language itself, and

22
00:00:59.006 --> 00:01:00.810
Justin it goes beyond that though.

23
00:01:00.810 --> 00:01:02.320
What exactly is Python?

24
00:01:02.320 --> 00:01:06.100
What makes it different than
other forms of programming?

25
00:01:06.100 --> 00:01:11.470
>> So, Python is very interesting, that
the whole purpose that it was devised,

26
00:01:11.470 --> 00:01:15.780
was to make it easy and
entry level to get a lot of things done.

27
00:01:15.780 --> 00:01:20.280
It's meant to be incredibly powerful
while we're moving away from

28
00:01:20.280 --> 00:01:25.440
all those arduous semicolons and
curly braces and parenthesis.

29
00:01:25.440 --> 00:01:30.820
But with all this power comes great
responsibility, just like Uncle Ben said.

30
00:01:30.820 --> 00:01:31.340
>> That's right.

31
00:01:31.340 --> 00:01:32.460
Uncle Ben is not a liar.

32
00:01:32.460 --> 00:01:33.770
The man knows his stuff.

33
00:01:33.770 --> 00:01:37.686
Well when it comes to Python,
really what makes it, what separates it?

34
00:01:37.686 --> 00:01:39.730
And obviously you said it's more simple,

35
00:01:39.730 --> 00:01:44.460
it's not as I guess complex as

36
00:01:44.460 --> 00:01:47.150
C tends to be quite complex

37
00:01:47.150 --> 00:01:52.050
Python has the same kind of power, yet
a whole lot less of the complexity.

38
00:01:52.050 --> 00:01:54.180
>> Yeah.
So there's this really smart guy

39
00:01:54.180 --> 00:01:58.270
named Guido Van [INAUDIBLE] I hope
I pronounced his name correctly.

40
00:01:58.270 --> 00:02:03.280
He's Dutch, so very sorry if I
mispronounced the name there.

41
00:02:03.280 --> 00:02:07.880
But his entire goal was to create
a language that was meant for

42

43
00:02:13.030 --> 00:02:16.160
So instead of having all

44

you know as you get the semi-colons,
the weird curly braces,

45
00:02:20.400 --> 00:02:25.840
and who knows what else, the goal was to

46

and remove all those things became

47
00:02:30.760 --> 00:02:34.300
And it just so happened he's
really good at what he does so

48
00:02:34.300 --> 00:02:36.540
it became very very powerful.

49
00:02:36.540 --> 00:02:37.860
>> Well, we sure do thank him for

50
00:02:37.860 --> 00:02:39.970
that because I don't know
about you guys out there,

51
00:02:39.970 --> 00:02:44.280
I've tried my hand at programming from

52

53

And you try to get into them.

54
00:02:50.820 --> 00:02:54.430
And it just seems like they

55
00:02:54.430 --> 00:02:55.930

56
00:02:55.930 --> 00:02:57.960
It's like,
I'm here to learn this language,

57
00:02:57.960 --> 00:03:02.130
not have to already kind of know it
before I'm able to understand it.

58
00:03:02.130 --> 00:03:06.150
That seems where Python, anytime I ask
someone what's the best language to get

59
00:03:06.150 --> 00:03:10.460
into if I'm a beginner, Python invariably

60
00:03:10.460 --> 00:03:14.030
And obviously that's because it's
meant to be end user friendly.

61
00:03:14.030 --> 00:03:17.900
If you don't know languages, you can jump
in there and you don't need to know much

62
00:03:17.900 --> 00:03:22.620

have to do is start learning, see how this

63

and I guess that's a good place for

64

65
00:03:32.430 --> 00:03:35.950
>> Well,
before I answer the what is the program,

66
00:03:35.950 --> 00:03:38.830
I just wanna give a general
statement about Python.

67
00:03:38.830 --> 00:03:41.380
So, you said it was a scripting language.

68
00:03:41.380 --> 00:03:47.220
It very much is kind of a replacement for
Bash or Pearl or VB Script.

69
00:03:48.410 --> 00:03:51.670
That's actually one of the first

70

very easy to get started,
easy to set up on most platforms.

71
00:03:56.010 --> 00:04:01.946
It's kind of already baked into the Star
Nix systems, so we'll get up and rolling.

72
00:04:01.946 --> 00:04:06.222
[COUGH]
Excuse me.

73
00:04:06.222 --> 00:04:09.230
But what is a programming language?

74
00:04:09.230 --> 00:04:13.270
The whole purpose of Python is to give
you something easy that you can write and

75
00:04:13.270 --> 00:04:14.520

76
00:04:14.520 --> 00:04:17.220
And then there's this special
thing called an interpreter.

77
00:04:17.220 --> 00:04:19.035
We can think of it as a little black box.

78
00:04:19.035 --> 00:04:20.620
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's hanging right here,

79
00:04:20.620 --> 00:04:21.380

80
00:04:22.570 --> 00:04:26.760
So we take that language, that text and
we feed it in and then there's magic.

81
00:04:26.760 --> 00:04:28.700
Effectively we're gonna say it's magic.

82
00:04:28.700 --> 00:04:33.680
And it comes out into machine

83
00:04:33.680 --> 00:04:38.960
when I type print, I want you to
output to the standard output.

84
00:04:38.960 --> 00:04:39.550
Things like that.

85
00:04:39.550 --> 00:04:43.080
So a programming language is a way
to interface with the computer

86
00:04:43.080 --> 00:04:46.860
in commonly understood English verbage.

87
00:04:46.860 --> 00:04:47.650
>> Yeah, and

88
00:04:47.650 --> 00:04:51.240
I guess you make a really good point there
is I did call it a scripting language.

89
00:04:51.240 --> 00:04:55.280
And from what I understand you can do
scripting with it as you just said.

90
00:04:55.280 --> 00:05:00.010
But it more properly is a programing
language we're scripting, it typically

91
00:05:00.010 --> 00:05:03.150
that's a line by line interpretation,
it just starts from the top, and

92
00:05:03.150 --> 00:05:06.700

93
00:05:06.700 --> 00:05:09.870

see what the problem is.

94
00:05:09.870 --> 00:05:14.140
Well programming language, it becomes more

95
00:05:15.340 --> 00:05:18.640
>> Yeah, so Python wears many hats.

96
00:05:18.640 --> 00:05:22.690
You can use it as a replacement for
Bash scripting, as I said.

97
00:05:22.690 --> 00:05:27.990

98
00:05:27.990 --> 00:05:29.310
That's where we're gonna start.

99
00:05:29.310 --> 00:05:33.740
But then you can do object
oriented programming which for

100
00:05:33.740 --> 00:05:37.018

101
00:05:37.018 --> 00:05:39.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> Functional programming It has access to

102

103
00:05:45.090 --> 00:05:48.970
It's called a batteries included

00:05:48.970 --> 00:05:54.880

105
00:05:54.880 --> 00:05:56.260
Hit the interwebs a little bit and

I'm like, hey, that's already

107
00:05:59.650 --> 00:06:03.570
So very, very broad in it's capabilities.

108
00:06:03.570 --> 00:06:07.590

things that you would any other

109

110
00:06:12.020 --> 00:06:15.980
if something goes wrong, it kinda give
an error, something will come up, and

111

112
00:06:16.860 --> 00:06:19.880
Do we get the same kind of

113
00:06:19.880 --> 00:06:21.990
>> We'll get the same type of output.

114
00:06:21.990 --> 00:06:26.450
Since it's not a compiled language,
which means the language is taken and

115
00:06:26.450 --> 00:06:31.080

understandable instructions first,

116
00:06:31.080 --> 00:06:35.320

Python kind of interprets that as it runs.

117
00:06:35.320 --> 00:06:38.960
So, you'll find that there will be errors

118
00:06:38.960 --> 00:06:41.730

and then it'll just eh!

119
00:06:41.730 --> 00:06:43.178
It'll just error out, and you're like.

120
00:06:43.178 --> 00:06:46.614
That's interesting.

121
00:06:46.614 --> 00:06:48.640
So cuz it's an interpretive language,

122
00:06:48.640 --> 00:06:52.800
just like that, it runs like a Bash
script, we will have errors.

123
00:06:52.800 --> 00:06:55.660
But it's pretty friendly about

124
00:06:55.660 --> 00:06:59.650
And we'll be able to see some

125
00:06:59.650 --> 00:07:03.550
>> All right, well I guess now we kind of
understand a little bit of what Python is,

126
00:07:03.550 --> 00:07:04.930

127
00:07:04.930 --> 00:07:08.030
A good place to go would be to let's
get this thing set up and running.

128
00:07:09.130 --> 00:07:11.200
Does it run on every platform or

129

130
00:07:14.950 --> 00:07:16.040
>> That's a great question.

131
00:07:16.040 --> 00:07:21.220
As I said, and you know, Linux, Unix
type systems, it's typically baked in.

132
00:07:21.220 --> 00:07:22.829
Especially newer distros like.

133
00:07:23.880 --> 00:07:27.140
Red Hat, any Red Hat distribution,
or Ubuntu.

134
00:07:28.640 --> 00:07:33.850
As well as OS X, they come with
a standard Python distribution baked in.

135
00:07:33.850 --> 00:07:37.930
And actually, Linux comes with two
versions, and that's where it gets weird.

136
00:07:37.930 --> 00:07:40.140
We have to talk about
the two version issue.

137
00:07:41.520 --> 00:07:44.370
And I'll show you that when
we get to the installer.

138
00:07:44.370 --> 00:07:48.140
For Windows, I'm gonna show
you where everybody can go and

139
00:07:48.140 --> 00:07:49.620

140
00:07:49.620 --> 00:07:52.466
You're up and
running in a matter of minutes.

141
00:07:52.466 --> 00:07:55.066
So yeah, it's pretty easy to get started.

142
00:07:55.066 --> 00:07:59.801
Great thing about Python cuz I have tried
some other languages that I'm like,

143
00:07:59.801 --> 00:08:01.242
okay, what am I doing?

144
00:08:01.242 --> 00:08:04.936
I gotta set what, I set a path and
there's this thing and then,

145
00:08:04.936 --> 00:08:08.700
it just keeps screaming at me and

146
00:08:08.700 --> 00:08:10.130

147
00:08:10.130 --> 00:08:14.810
Let's jump into your computer there and

148
00:08:14.810 --> 00:08:16.550
How do we interface with this thing?

149
00:08:16.550 --> 00:08:17.410
How do we get his working?

150
00:08:17.410 --> 00:08:22.341
If I wanted to write a script, where would

152
00:08:25.453 --> 00:08:28.090

So there's a multitude of ways that you

153
00:08:28.090 --> 00:08:32.673

Python scripts, running Python scripts.

154
00:08:32.673 --> 00:08:36.643
I'm gonna take kind of almost
like a systems approach,

155
00:08:36.643 --> 00:08:41.380
cuz I use this not only for
kind of making full blown applications.

156
00:08:41.380 --> 00:08:46.419
I also use it to automate some processes,

157
00:08:46.419 --> 00:08:50.445
But before we worry about how to interface
with that, let's just take a look,

158
00:08:50.445 --> 00:08:52.397

159

Well, the Python organization

Fun fact, this was designed by

Interesting, interesting fact.

166
00:09:13.920 --> 00:09:15.248

00:09:15.248 --> 00:09:16.536

168

169

00:09:27.060 --> 00:09:31.707
But if you come to the downloads here,

00:09:31.707 --> 00:09:34.584

172
00:09:34.584 --> 00:09:39.169
Let's just take a quick look at other
platforms, I don't even know what that is.

173
00:09:39.169 --> 00:09:41.920

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin start building your foundational Python vocabulary. They explain Python objects like Variables and Values (which are stored in variables) as well as logical operators/operands. They also cover what to do when things go awry and you have to "debug" your code, and how to keep your code descriptive by employing comments.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin take you to the next level with Python by showing you how to create more intelligent programs through the use of decision making. They start by looking at boolean expressions and logical operators and then using those values to make a decision through the employ of If, Else, and Elif statements.
episodes.title: Decision Making in Python

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin explore how to make your Python code more modular by introducing Functions. They begin by explaining what a function is and how to create one or many, and even use functions nested inside other functions to create a more structured program/script.
episodes.title: Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin take a look at how to use Python to perform repetitive tasks, a process known as iteration or loops. They begin by explaining the structure and use of While loops and then show you some examples to demonstrate how while loops iterate. They also explain how to avoid infinite loops by breaking the loop through decision statements.
episodes.title: Iterations

And So while True take user_input and

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin take a closer look at Strings in Python. They explain the structure of Strings through which they are able to introduce you to the concept and practice of Slicing. They also cover another useful concept known as Zero Based Indexing, which leads them to their final topic of another iteration process called For loops.
episodes.title: Strings and more Iteration

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin explain how to use Lists in Python. They start off by defining what lists are and what they can be comprised of. Then they compare the similarities and differences of Lists with Strings. Next, they show you how to access the elements in a list as well as how to use List Operations, Slicing with Lists, and modifying Lists.
episodes.title: Lists

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin acquaint you with yet another invaluable Python container, that container being Dictionaries. They explain exactly what a Dictionary is; contrasting it against Lists. They show you how to use all the standard operations that we've learned, as well as how to iterate through elements in the Dictionary.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin familiarize you with Tuples in Python. Though it may have an unusual name, Tuples are very similar to Lists, but with some important differences. Here, Justin describes exactly what Tuples are and gives some great examples of how and where one might use them. They also show you how to use the standard operating methods and slicing techniques applied to Tuples. Finally, they show you how you can use Tuples as input to Functions.

00:01:48.950 --> 00:01:54.030

00:02:08.095 --> 00:02:09.388

00:02:13.708 --> 00:02:18.029

00:02:30.830 --> 00:02:36.120

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin show you how to use Python to manipulate text files. They begin by showing you open files and read the content out to Python. Then they introduce you to the With statement as an easy way to close files once your program is done with them. They also show you how to write to files, which adds useful functions to your programs.
episodes.title: Manipulating Files

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin jump back to Functions for a more in-depth look at the Standard Library. In the previous episode on Python Functions you learned how to create your own custom function. Here, the guys show you how to take advantage of the myriad of built-in Functions found in any Python install.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin show you how to take all they've taught you so far and put it to use in one program. They use variables, lists, dictionaries, file manipulation, etc. to create a program that parses through text files, looks for desired text, and outputs to a comma separated value(CSV) file for further analysis. This is a culmination of all your new Python skills!
